awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Active and Rapid Domain Generalization
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in machine learning have enabled a wide range of practical applications including active authentication, autonomous driving, and medical diagnosis. While machine learning algorithms achieve impressive performances for these applications, they have to constantly deal with changing characteristics of input data. Examples of such cases include: recognizing faces under poor lighting conditions and side poses while algorithms are trained on well-illuminated faces at the frontal pose; and detecting and segmenting an organ of interest from low-resolution medical images when available algorithms are instead optimized for high-resolution medical images. This problem is commonly known as domain shift. The accuracies of machine learning systems decrease significantly when domain shifts are present. As a result, users must spend significant amounts of time and money to rebuild machine learning models to work well on new data. This project aims to develop computational methods for automatically detecting the presence of domain shifts, quickly adapting machine learning systems to new data distribution, and intelligently seeking additional information to improve the system's performance. Research outputs of this project, such as software, publications, and best practices will contribute to making a wide range of machine learning systems less vulnerable to perpetual changes of input data, and safer to use in the presence of domain shifts. 

To achieve these goals, this project proposes four main thrusts: 1) constructing meta-learning techniques to enable efficient adaptation of classifiers to unseen domains using unlabeled data; 2) developing an optimal reinforcement learning strategy for querying additional information that allows effective generalization when the uncertainty is high; 3) building algorithmic foundations for detecting the presence of domain shifts and preparing machine learning systems for appropriate actions; and 4) validating the proposed approaches with classification and segmentation tasks from large-scale datasets corresponding to autonomous driving and active mobile authentication applications. This project combines recent advances in variational inference, reinforcement learning, and active learning to bring a modern and unique perspective on how to deal with the problem of domain shift.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project funded by NSF under award number 1910973 focused on advancing machine learning techniques for efficiently adapting to new data distributions in various applications such as medical imaging, brain image analysis, and seismic data processing. The overall goal was to develop methods to detect domain shifts in data, adapt to new datasets, and intelligently query information to improve system performance. Over the course of the project, significant advancements were made in the fields of few-shot learning, meta-learning, active learning, and uncertainty estimation.

Intellectual Merit:The project yielded several groundbreaking results:


1. Memory-Augmented Capsule Networks for Lung Nodule Classification: One of the most impactful outcomes was the development of a memory-augmented capsule network that significantly reduced the error rate in lung nodule classification. The model reduced the classification error from 28% to 11%, which was crucial in improving diagnostic accuracy for lung cancer screening using low-dose CT scans.   

2. Bayesian Meta-Learning for Brain Cell Classification: The team developed a novel Bayesian meta-learning method that enabled efficient adaptation of deep networks to unseen data distributions. This method was applied to brain cell classification, enabling high accuracy even with limited data. Additionally, the model achieved transfer learning from rat brain cells to human brain cells, which is pivotal in brain research and medical applications.


3. Active Meta-Learning for Efficient Data Annotation: The project also led to a breakthrough in active learning, where the team developed an algorithm that intelligently queried the most informative samples for annotation. This significantly reduced the amount of data required for training machine learning models while maintaining high performance.


These advancements were not only scientifically significant but also applied to real-world challenges. The research enabled improvements in medical image analysis (e.g., lung nodule detection), robotic-assisted structural monitoring (e.g., detecting joint looseness), and seismic data processing (e.g., first arrival picking). The results from this work have been widely disseminated through 15 publications in highly regarded journals and conferences, including IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging, Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention, and Scientific Reports.


Broader Impacts:The broader impacts of this work are far-reaching, with contributions to both academia and industry:


1. Training and Professional Development: The project supported the training of four doctoral students and three undergraduate students. These students were directly involved in the research and had the opportunity to attend international conferences, gaining exposure to cutting-edge research and networking with experts in the field. The project’s interdisciplinary nature also fostered collaboration among researchers in machine learning, medical imaging, robotics, and neuroscience.
2. Real-World Applications and Technology Transfer: One of the most impactful real-world applications of the research is the development of a platform for immune cell and brain cell analysis. This platform, co-founded by Dr. Navin Varadarajan from the University of Houston, is being commercialized by CellChorus and is expected to accelerate drug discovery and improve the evaluation of drug efficacy. This demonstrates the potential for translating academic research into tangible benefits for society.
3. Educational Impact: The findings from this project were incorporated into the curriculum for advanced machine learning and deep learning courses taught by the principal investigator (PI) at the University of Houston. This allowed students to benefit from the latest research and applications in these fields.


In summary, the project has made significant contributions to machine learning research, particularly in the areas of meta-learning, uncertainty estimation, and domain adaptation. It has also facilitated important real-world applications in medical imaging, robotics, and drug discovery. The training of doctoral students, significant number of high quality publications, and the commercialization of the research outcomes are clear indicators of the project's success in advancing both scientific knowledge and societal impact.
